Known Topologies Module¶

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_alexandrov_topology(space, order_relation)¶

Create the Alexandrov topology on the given space based on an order relation.

The Alexandrov topology is a topology where arbitrary intersections of open sets are also open. This is particularly useful in domain theory and order theory, as it ensures that the collection of open sets is closed under arbitrary intersections, making it easier to work with in theoretical frameworks.

In the Alexandrov topology, for each element \(x\) in the space, the “upper set” containing all elements greater than or equal to \(x\) (according to the order relation) forms an open set.

Example

Consider the set \(\{a, b, c\}\) with the following order relation:

  • \(a \leq b\)

  • \(b \leq c\)

The upper sets would be:

  • \(\{a, b, c\}\) (starting from \(a\))

  • \(\{b, c\}\) (starting from \(b\))

  • \(\{c\}\) (starting from \(c\))

In this example, the open sets in the Alexandrov topology are arbitrary unions of these upper sets, along with the empty set.

Parameters:

  • space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

  • order_relation (Callable) – A function that takes two elements \(x, y\) and returns True if \(x \leq y\).

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the Alexandrov topology.

Return type:

Topology

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_discrete_topology(space)¶

Create a discrete topology on the given space.

A discrete topology on a set \(X\) is the topology in which every subset of \(X\) is open. This means the topology \(\tau\) is equal to the power set of \(X\).

\[\tau = \mathcal{P}(X)\]

Example

A function from any space with a discrete topology to any topology is continuous.

Parameters:

space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the discrete topology.

Return type:

Topology

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_divisibility_topology(space)¶

Create an excluded point topology on the given space.

An excluded point topology on a set \(X\) is defined such that the only open sets are those that do not contain a particular point \(e \in X\), plus the entire set and the empty set.

Parameters:

  • space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

  • excluded_point – The point that is excluded from all non-empty open sets.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the excluded point topology.

Return type:

Topology

Raises:

ValueError – If the excluded point is not an element of the space.

Create an excluded point topology on the given space.

An excluded point topology on a set \(X\) is defined such that the only open sets are those that do not contain a particular point \(e \in X\), plus the entire set and the empty set.

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_particular_point_topology(space, particular_point)¶

Create a particular point topology on the given space.

A particular point topology on a set \(X\) is defined such that every non-empty open set must include a distinguished point \(p \in X\).

Example

In a particular point topology, the only continuous functions are the constant ones or those mapping the distinguished point to any open set.

Parameters:

  • space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

  • particular_point – The distinguished point that must be included in all non-empty open sets.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the particular point topology.

Return type:

Topology

Raises:

ValueError – If the particular point is not an element of the space.

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_sierpinski_topology()¶

Create the Sierpiński topology.

The Sierpiński topology is defined on the set \(\{0, 1\}\) with the collection of open sets being \(\{ \emptyset, \{1\}, \{0, 1\} \}\).

Example

The Sierpiński topology is important in domain theory and theoretical computer science.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the Sierpiński topology.

Return type:

Topology

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_topology_from_equivalence(space, equivalence_relation)¶

Create a topology on the given space based on an equivalence relation.

The open sets in this topology are defined as unions of equivalence classes.

Parameters:

  • space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

  • equivalence_relation (function) – A function that takes two elements and returns True if they are equivalent.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the topology based on the equivalence relation.

Return type:

Topology

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_trivial_topology(space)¶

Create a trivial (indiscrete) topology on the given space.

A trivial topology (also known as indiscrete topology) on a set \(X\) contains only the empty set and the entire set itself.

\[\tau = \{ \emptyset, X \}\]

Example

A function to any space with the trivial topology is always continuous.

Parameters:

space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the trivial topology.

Return type:

Topology

finite_topology.known_topologies.create_upward_closed_topology(space, order_relation)¶

Create a topology where open sets are upward-closed sets in a partial order.

An upward-closed set (or upper set) contains, along with each of its elements, all elements greater than or equal to it in the given order.

This type of topology is useful in order theory and domain theory, particularly in theoretical computer science and lattice theory.

Example

Consider the set \(\{1, 2, 3\}\) with the usual ordering of integers. In this case, the upward-closed sets would be:

  • \(\emptyset\) (the empty set),

  • \(\{1, 2, 3\}\) (the entire set),

  • \(\{2, 3\}\) (the set containing 2 and all elements greater than 2),

  • \(\{3\}\) (the set containing 3 alone).

Parameters:

  • space (set) – The set on which the topology is defined.

  • order_relation (dict) – A mapping where order_relation[x] is a set of elements greater than or equal to x.

Returns:

An instance of the Topology class representing the upward-closed topology.

Return type:

Topology
